key_points: Facebook suspended Donald Trump for two years due to severe violation of its rules after the Capitol riots.
Trump's suspension to end just in time for the 2024 election cycle, with reinstatement depending on public safety risk assessment.
Trump condemned Facebook's decision, calling it an insult and hinted at no "dinners" with Zuckerberg if he's re-elected.
The Biden White House doubts Trump's behavioral change post-suspension, emphasizing responsibility on platforms to control misinformation.
Facebook's decision alters its policy to stop granting politicians exemptions from content rules, introducing penalties for fomenting violence.
Facebook's vice president of global affairs and communications, Nick Clegg, described Trump’s actions as a severe violation deserving the highest penalty.
Trump’s ban from Facebook and Instagram was initially indefinite, following his support for Capitol rioters.
Trump's Facebook suspension limits his fundraising capabilities for the 2022 Republican candidates.
Critics from both political spectrums expressed dissatisfaction, with some seeing it as too lenient and others as censorship.
The suspension decision followed a directive from Facebook's Oversight Board, which deemed an indefinite suspension inappropriate.
spokespersons: Nick Clegg (Facebook's vice president of global affairs and communications)
